uh S3 for all these purposes and some others as well okay all right so just a
sample application that I want to talk to you guys about today is for the Mars exploration Rovers these are the Rovers that have been on Mars since 2004 uh
these Rovers uh were supposed to last for 90 days except they ended up going for eight years and they're still going
and some of our data started getting really big and some of our internal infrastructure started kind of crumbling under under the the amount of data that
we had to mention to hold on to and uh so we started looking to ways looking for ways to migrate our data processing
data storage and data delivery mechanisms via S3 so all of the images that are coming down from the Rover are
now actually stored on S3 and as soon as we do that we're able to enjoy the durability that we get out of the 11 the
11 NES of durability that we get out of storing the images in S3 but also now all of a sudden we have web-based URLs
that we can provide to people with links to the images especially the images that are you know uh that we want to be able
that we want our scientists to be able to collaborate around more importantly all the plans that the scientists made
for the what the Rover is going to do the next day are stored in S3 a lot of people think Mars rovers are operated
out of joysticks uh unfortunately you can't do that because at the speed of light it takes seven minutes to get to
Mars so what we do is we actually decide what the Rover is going to do over an entire day and we put that in a plan and
we send that over to the Rover so all these plans are stored on S3 and
scientists collaborate around these plans in terms of you know one scientist will upload the plan the other scientist
will download these plans edit it and then where work through that life cycle now these plans are sensitive data
because they have some of our U uh sensitive activities that uh the names of activities that we don't want to get
out in case somebody wants to hack our systems so this is sensitive data and in order to do that we do on-site
encryption so before our uh client application uploads these data onto S3 it will actually encrypt it on site and
then when it downloads the encrypted files it will decrypt the data on the application itself so this allows us to
keep uh Sensi information on S3 by encrypting on premise which I think is a pretty good design pattern because it
allows us to uh enjoy the low operations cost high durability High availability
uh for our sensor of applications without having to compromise the Integrity or the privacy of our data

have a slide there so uh we have a tool called versioning uh which enables you to it's a Bucket Level configuration
which you can specify to uh to keep every version of an object that has ever
existed in your bucket so if I write a key named Dan uh and then I overwrite
that key with named Dan with with new data uh on the following day and I overwrite it again with new data on the
day after that if I have versioning on uh the S3 bucket will actually contain three objects now a simple list of the
bucket will only show the one it will show Dan but if I then apply versioned list I will actually see all three and I
can use a version get operation to get any one of them so one of the really nice aspects of that is that if you have
an application today that's running on S3 or you write one in the future uh that's not using versioning you can turn
on versioning and it doesn't change the behavior of the application at all deletes Contin to operate the way they
normally do your list only shows you essentially the current version of the bucket but if you use the versioned
operations on the bucket you can then dig into past versions of data uh and if you want you can uh you can remove if
you decide that you're that you're comfortable you can start purging older versions by uh by using a version delete
operation uh but this this provides you protection from a bug in the application or an operator error in the console uh
or any number of things the other tool that works really well with with this one as well is uh the IM am credential
so when you saw Dan's eclipse cons Eclipse IDE um the credentials that you

number every 60 seconds uh and and is physically then added to the API so uh
this is a mechanism actually I know businesses that store critical data in critical business data in S3 and have

versions okay next we'll look at how we can save
money on S3 uh by archiving data and eventually expiring data that we no longer need so uh the tools that we use
here are S3 Glacier uh which is a new storage class in or it's a new storage
mechanism in S3 uh and object exploration so imagine that you have an app that generates uh gigabytes or even
terabytes of logs a day um that data is useful to you for a period of time you
go back to it you know every uh every so often in the first month or two uh but maybe after three months you find you're
not really accessing that log data except for every once in a blue moon but you don't want to get rid of
it Amazon S3 Glacier and exploration provide you a mechanism to store the data that you need to actually access
regularly in standard storage with with rapid access uh and then archive the older log data
into S3 Glacier where it will be stored cheaply but require some time to get access
to so let's take a look at a demo of how we actually do

bucket and under the properties for the bucket we'll go down to life cycle and we'll click on ADD
Rule now at this point uh I can choose to keep it enabled I can specify a name and then I can decide whether my rule is
going to apply to the entire bucket or just a portion of the bucket in this case let's say that I'm interested in
archiving just my logs so I'll specify a prefix logs and then I'll look at adding
a transition so adding a transition uh enables me to specify an age at which objects should move to Glacier so maybe
in this case I want uh quick access to uh logs for 90 days and after that I'm
I'm okay with with them being in archival storage uh so I'll specify 90
days here now for the first 90 days of their life these objects under the logs prefix will be stored in S3 standard
storage uh which we were excited to announce a big price drop on yesterday uh and then after 90 days they'll be
transitioned to Glacier storage which is dramatically cheaper even than that uh at 1 cent per gigabyte for
storage now let's say that I also am not interested in keeping these logs Beyond
a certain point at all so maybe uh after a year I don't need to keep them so I'll
specify an expiration of 365 days so the behavior here will be uh objects will be
written into the logs prefix and for the first 90 days they'll stay in standard after 90 days they'll be transitioned to
Glacier and they'll stay in Glacier storage until the object is a year old from its original right and then at the
365 day Mark we'll delete it automatically for you and I'll go ahead and hit save now
we warn you because uh uh this is a kind of an important management operation we're taking here uh that objects which
are being transitioned into Glacier are not immediately available when you want them you uh you specify uh you you issue
a restore command and we bring it back to uh to availability in S3 within 3 to
5 hours um so you can uh you can make it available within a few hours but it will not be uh accessible immediately to gets

uh and the ease of use of archiving objects that you have written in S3 directly into Glacier uh life cycle
rules enable me to automatically move these objects uh and once I've archived
an object it's still listable in the S3 API so I can still list my logs prefix and it will show me objects of any age
um but those of the those objects that are still in S3 standard storage are immediately getable and objects that
